Updating from 0/20/79/1/0 on Q3 report [1]. We are at 271.4k deliveries in the question period so far, with only the contribution of 2019Q4 remaining to be seen. I daresay the forecasts that have centered on the production bottleneck have been borne out, while forecasts focusing on demand have not. From the 2019Q3 report: "[W]e achieved record net orders in Q3 and are entering Q4 with an increase in our order backlog. As was also the case in Q2, nearly all of our Model 3 orders were received from customers who did not previously hold a reservation, solidifying the transition to generating strong organic demand. " The 2019Q3 numbers also show that Tesla is struggling to break the ~6k/week production barrier, having averaged 79,600/13 ~ 6.1k Model 3s per week in 2019Q3, not that different from 2019Q2. In terms of buckets, we need 58.6k to hit 330k (all but certain in my view) and 108.6k to hit 380k (almost impossible in my view). To hit 380k Tesla would need to have started making ~8.4k Model 3s per week, 2-4 weeks ago. To fail to hit 330k, we'd need to see a big demand shock, breaking the trend (since 2013) that Q4 sales are close to or higher than Q3. [1] https://ir.tesla.com/news-releases/news-release-details/tesla-q3-2019-vehicle-production-deliveries

330,000 4,507 per week
380,000 8,353 per week
430,000 12,199 per week The unknown is China. Chinese media reported at the end of September that the Gigafactory 3 stamping area and paint shop are ready to begin operation and the first "body in white" has rolled off the production line; "Body in white (BIW) corresponds to a stage in car manufacturing wherein a vehicle’s components are fully joined together. This is done through several means, ranging from welding, riveting, clinching, and laser brazing, to name a few. BIW is termed prior to the vehicle being painted, and before components such as engines (or drive units for that matter), and trim have been assembled into a frame." [5]. I struggle to get my head around the idea of going from a bare piece of land in December 2018 to a finished 9.3 million sq. ft. 21st century factory in November 2019. The rate of progress is astonishing. However I'm now a believer - I think they could begin Model 3 production in Shanghai this year. Will GF3 produce enough units to get deliveries into the next bucket? I don't think so. If the Fremont factory takes deliveries up to about 352k (assuming similar numbers in Q4 as in Q3) then GF3 would need to deliver 28,000 Model 3's in order to get us into the next bucket. Assuming GF3 came online towards the end of November it would have to produce 28,000 units in 4 weeks, i.e. 7,000 per week which I think is not feasible. Crowd: 5%, 20%, 65%, 6%, 4%. Right now the numbers are 2018 Q4 + 2019 (Q1+Q2+Q3) = 63554 + 50928 + 77634 + 79600 = 271716 units sold, approximately. If I assume for Q4 85000 (Q4 seems to be associated to higher deliveries) plus/minus 15000 as sigma, and a Gaussian distribution, this will give 0.0, 3.6, 90.1, 6.3, 0.0 % for each of the brackets in the question. If I assume 90000 for Q4, which might happen if the Chinese market continues is large growth, the probabilities would be 0.0, 1.6, 86.8, 11.5, 0.0. Averaging the two (a bit on the lower side for the 280k-330k bracket), I arrive to my estimation.

I'm not changing my delivery forecast of 351k, just tightening the spread a little. It looks like the Chinese Gigafactory is an assembly plant specifically designed to get round import tariffs for FBU (Full-built-up) cars, not a full production line. So Model 3 kits would be made in California then shipped to Shanghai for final assembly. Presumably this will mean a fair amount of reorganisation during Q3 and have a negative impact on deliveries by delaying them until Q4. So in the same way that reorganisation and shipping delays to Europe impacted overall deliveries in Q1, shipping the kits to China will impact deliveries in Q3 by delaying them until Q4.

https://www.theverge.com/2019/7/24/20708462/tesla-q2-earnings-loss-model-3-elon-musk "Tesla plans to deliver between 360,000 and 400,000 cars across all of 2019, and thanks to its slower first quarter, will have to keep operating at its torrid second-quarter pace in order to do that. The company is nearing the completion of its third Gigafactory, located in China. Getting production up and running there could help the company meet, or maybe even beat, that delivery goal for the year. Despite a recent downturn, China is still the biggest market for electric cars in the world. Making cars locally will help Tesla get around existing import taxes on the Model 3, which could theoretically boost sales there.

Tesla Q2 Shareholder Letter [5]: "The production rate of Model 3 continued to improve gradually throughout the quarter, breaking a monthly record in May and then again in June. All manufacturing equipment in Fremont has demonstrated capability of a 7,000 Model 3 vehicles per week run rate, which we continue to work to increase." As you can see, production rate has not gone down like the delivery dip in 2019 Q1. This was due to deliveries beginning in Europe and China [4 - Tesla Q1 shareholder letter]. In addition, Tesla reports that production rates have hit monthly records in May and June. Therefore, I don't expect production/delivery rate to lower in 2019 Q3 and Q4. Running my production model again, which forecasts deliveries based on weekly production rate and assume production-delivery lag. Assuming a linear increase from 6k at end of H1 2019 to 7k at end of H2 2019 and a 4 week lag, I get ~355k. Previously this analysis resulted in a similar number (slightly smaller) but I still placed a higher probability on the lower bucket because I didn't take the Tesla 7k target at face value. However, I am now adjusting that view and assume there is a higher chance that Tesla hits the 7k by year end. There are three reasons for this:
1) Tesla had a record Q2, with orders exceeding deliveries, implying an increase in backlog.
2) Tesla is planning to increase production and is hiring more workers. This is not the behavior of a manufacturer that is constrained by demand. [1,2] "Tesla has said it plans to produce “significantly” more than the 360,000 to 400,000 vehicles the company expects to deliver in 2019. Musk had promised the company would be building 500,000 cars a year by the end of last year." [1] So far in 2019, Model 3 production has equaled 82% of total production. These targets imply: Total   Model 3
360k   358
400k   391
500k   474 (EDIT: worth pointing out that the 500k target is very likely not a delivery target for the year but more of a target for what the rate of production/delivery would be at the end of the year) 3) The construction of the Chinese factory which I previously assumed wouldn't be operational this year seems to be doing well though hard to say if it's ahead of schedule or not. [1] "Output may reach 500,000 vehicles worldwide this year if its factory now under construction near Shanghai can reach “volume production” early in the fourth quarter, the company told shareholders in April.
“The stamping, body, paint, and general assembly lines in China are well underway and hitting records in both line design and fabrication,” Guillen said." [1] https://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-hy-tesla-production-hiring-20190710-story.html

Updating from 8/47/44/1/0 in light of 2019Q2 numbers [1]. We are now at 191.8k delivered M3s, with "7,400 vehicles in transit", which works out to ~6k M3s in transit if we work out the fractions. I believe this lets us rule out the top two buckets. Even counting the 6k in transit, in order to break 380k, Tesla would need to have started producing 7k/week on 1 July 2019, and deliver every last car they made, even the ones made on 31 Dec 2019. Obviously that won't happen; they are currently making ~6k/week, and it takes at least 2 weeks to deliver a car, probably more like 4 weeks on average. Even if China factory comes online soon, it can't make up for the shortfall of at least a quarter producing 6k/week instead of 7k/week. So I zero out top bucket, and leave 1% in [380k,430k]. I ran my code from previous forecasts [2] but with the following updated info: # Density functions for US & China production
# US: 63,359 for 2018Q4                                                63.4k
#        50,900 for 2019Q1                                                50.9k
#        77,550 for 2019Q2                                                77.5k
#        23 weeks until 7 Dec 2019
#
#     TOTAL SO FAR                                                        191.8k
#     current average: ~6.0k/week
#     pessimistic: keep 6k/week thru 07 Dec (~4 weeks before 1 Jan 2020)  -- 329.8k
#     normal:      ramp linearly 6k -> 7k thru 07 Dec -- 341.3k
#     optimistic:  ramps linearly from 6k to 7k for rest of 2019Q3; stays at 7k for 2019Q4 -- 346.3k
#
# China: no production until 2019Q4 at least. Unlikely to make anything.
[usLow, usMid, usHigh] = [330, 341, 346]
[chinaLow, chinaMid, chinaHigh] = [0, 1, 3] The output of my program tells me to put 100% on the [330k,380k] bucket. That feels overconfident, not least because my code doesn't take demand into account at all. On the other hand, as I argued in a previous comment [3], there were conservatively 350k reservation holders at the start of the period in question, which is enough to get us into that bucket. I don't know how many cancel, but presumably some also acquire new reservations. A little more upside is given by the fact that Tesla has started selling cheaper used M3s [4], and there are over 70k M3s made in 2018Q3 or earlier. Still, I will temper the program's recommendation down to a 20/80 split since other good forecasters (@Emil, @nigster, @cafebedouin, @ddorsey) are far from 100% on any single bucket. That puts a floor, based on U.S. production only, of around 200,000 cars for the three quarters. Or, 310,000 if we add 112,000 from the first two quarters. This aligns pretty closely with: "Tesla delivered just 63,000 cars in the first quarter but expects to deliver 90,000 to 100,000 cars in the second quarter, and 360,000 to 400,000 for the year. Ives said hitting the full-year target is going to be a 'Herculean task' and sees 340,000 to 355,000 as a more likely scenario."[2]  Note: The most likely scenario described here is all Tesla cars. Let's assume Model 3s are 70% of deliveries, then the 238,000 to 250,000 for full year 2019 and then we need to add 61,000 for 2018Q1, which makes it 300,000 to 315,000, or in line with my estimate above. I think there are two unaccounted for variables. First, will Tesla be able to squeeze more cars out of their U.S. production line. My sense is that is a constrained factor, probably only accounting for <10,000 in variability.  Second, when will Chinese production come online? If we assume the Chinese factor comes online in September and makes an average of a 1,000 cars a week, that's 20,000 cars. But, I honestly have no idea what kind of ramp up to expect here. Will they start three lines of 1,000 a piece? Could they do as many as 2,000 a week per line on average for the period? It could be anywhere in the range of 20,000 to 100,000 additional vehicles. I'm going to put a small hedge on 280,000 but less than 330,000, just in case China doesn't come online or cannot produce cars at volume. But, I'm really skeptical that will be the case and am only going to hedge a little, 5%. It seems unlikely to me that the Chinese factory will get to 120,000 cars this year, so simple hedge of 5% on top option. Rest I'm going weight the third slightly more than the fourth option.  I think the Chinese factory makes it impossible to reduce the random chance further. Availability of a cheaper Model 3 at 35k changes the outlook (in particular, it means that deliveries may not be constrained by demand - more on that later) so I am revising my analysis.  Summary: a pure production-based analysis suggests a base case forecast of 368k. However, demand pulls the probability distribution down a bit. First, from a purely production perspective:  Production is currently just above 5k [1]. In January, Tesla said it will reach annualized production of 7k by year end. [2] That's for the US factory. They also said the Shanghai factory would be starting at a rate of 3k per week [2].  Later Musk tweeted he expected an annualized rate corresponding to 500k deliveries [3], implying a rate per week of 9,615 but it's not clear if he was talking about Model 3 or total. Assume he was talking just Model 3's. it seems he was talking about both factories, not just the US one (since the context of his tweet was total Tesla production).  Key consideration: does the China factory matter for the purpose of this question? Musk said: ""Aiming to finish initial construction this summer, start Model 3 production end of year & reach high volume production next year," the billionaire entrepreneur said." [4] This suggests that the Chinese factory should be out of the question.  Therefore, any forecasts that rely on Musk's tweet about annualized production by end of 2019 risk overestimating the actual production relevant for this question (If you take the current 5k and extrapolate linearly to the stated 9.6k by 2019, you will be overestimating since you will be accounting for growth toward the 9.6k that won't materialize linearly. Instead there will be a discrete step-jump once the China factory starts producing). So what could production actually look like purely based on Tesla statements? Start at 5k at the start of the year and raise linearly to 7k by end of year. This suggests production of 312k for 2019. Assuming deliveries lag production by two weeks, deliveries would be 307k. Adding the 61k from Q4 2018 would lead to a forecast of 368k. Second, from a demand perspective:  We know very little about demand for Model 3's. Initially Tesla had 400k+ reservations but as @nigster has shown [5] those have whittled down possibly to something like 260k or less. Tesla's tactics of reducing prices twice in the last couple of months further imply they have a demand problem. Tesla follower behind the crowdsourced spreadsheet who goes by Troy Teslike estimated new orders of 1700-2000 per week in the US [6]. Of course, that's before Tesla unveiled the 35k version.  The closing of showrooms might dent demand a little but I can easily see large throngs of people buying the car online (rough analogy - buying mattresses online seemed strange at first but it has proven very popular).  Still, demand could turn out weaker, and I assume it puts downward pressure on the probability distribution. [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/
[2] http://ir.tesla.com/static-files/0b913415-467d-4c0d-be4c-9225c2cb0ae0

def GetHeightOfMode(lowPoint, highPoint):
..return 2.0/(highPoint - lowPoint) def DensityFunction(lowPoint, midPoint, highPoint, x):
..h = GetHeightOfMode(lowPoint, highPoint)
..risingSlope = h/(midPoint - lowPoint)
..fallingSlope = -h/(highPoint - midPoint)
..if x <= lowPoint:
....return 0.0
..if lowPoint < x <= midPoint:
....return (x - lowPoint)*risingSlope
..if midPoint < x <= highPoint:
....return h + (x - midPoint)*fallingSlope
..if highPoint < x:

..return (lambda x : DensityFunction(lowPoint, midPoint, highPoint, x)) # Density functions for US & China production

Updating from 10/40/49/1/0 due to discussions at [1]. Thanks to @cafebedouin for bringing up good points. Most importantly, I had misread the weekly production graph in [2] as saying that prod rates had remained ~constant over the past 3 months, whereas the reality is they simply changed how the displayed rate is computed: "An update to the model on Oct. 2 adopted a 13-week trailing average for our weekly estimate." If I am reading the thin, light green bars right, they surpassed 6k/week for a couple of weeks, including the latest week. I've set it up as follows. There are two factories, US and China. For each one I came up with a pessimistic, a normal, and an optimistic output. Then I made a probability density for the true output in the simplest way: a triangle graph that starts at zero at the pessimistic output, peaks at the normal output, then decays again to zero at the optimistic output. (1) US factory:
* Pessimistic: keep 5k/week production rate constant throughout the year (260k total);
* Normal: linearly increases from current 4.6k/week to 7k/week at year-end (302k total);
* Optimistic: linearly increases from current 4.6k/week to 10k/week at year-end (380k total). (2) China factory:
* Pessimistic: comes online after Q3 (3 weeks into Q4) and only averages 1k/week for rest of year (10k total);
* Normal: China factory comes online precisely in the middle of 2019H2 and scales production linearly from 1k/week to 3k/week (26k total);
* Optimistic: China factory comes online early (6 weeks into) H2, and scales linearly from 2k/week to 5k/week (70k total). Then, assuming independence, the histogram for their sum is easy to compute by convolution. Here is the Python code: # Density function for US production
def US(q):
..if q <= 260:
....return 0.0
..if 260 < q <= 302:
....return (q-260.0)/(42*60)
..if 302 < q <= 380:
....return 1/60.0 - (q-302.0)/(78*60)
..if 380 < q:
....return 0.0 # Density function for China production
def China(q):
..if q <= 10:
....return 0.0
..if 10 < q <= 26:
....return (q-10.0)/(30*16)
..if 26 < q <= 70:
....return 1/30.0 - (q-26.0)/(30*44)
..if 70 < q:
....return 0.0 total = [0]*460
for s in range(0,460):
..total[s] = sum([ US(i)*China(s-i) for i in range(0,s+1) ]) [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/820690

In 2018Q4 we had 63,150 deliveries [1]. According to the Bloomberg tracker [2], Tesla is making 4,684 Model 3s per week. So the simplest prediction is 63,150 + 52x4,684 ~ 307k. This is almost exactly the middle of the second bucket. Yes, I am substituting "deliveries" for "production". There is so much demand for Model 3s that I believe the only bottleneck is production. In the 2018Q1 investor letter [3] they say there were over 450k reservations at 2018Q1 end. They delivered 18,449 in 2018Q2 [4] and 56,065 in 2018Q3 [5], so there must be at least ~375k reservations remaining for the Q period. And remember, they only stopped taking reservations because they moved to a direct order system now that production rates are up [5]. Let's try to discard some buckets. Apparently Musk said in 2016 that by 2020 Tesla would be making 500k cars per year. Now, (i) the norm for Musk is to wildly overpredict future performance; (ii) this Q is about 2019, not 2020; and (iii) It's 500k cars total, and the Q is about Model 3s (in 2018 there were ~100k non-Model 3 deliveries [1]). So I discard the >430k bucket, and give only 1% to 380k-430k. At the other end, for us to go under 280k, we'd have to average ~54.2k cars per quarter in 2019. This is less than the deliveries in Q3, when production was still ramping up. With the ramp up complete (in some way), a new factory in China planned for 2019H2 [6], and deliveries to start in Europe and China, it seems very unlikely to me that we would consistently underperform 2018Q3. Let's call it 10% since I don't know enough about this area to have "5%" levels of confidence. Now, how could we get to 330k-380k? The China factory is supposed to make 3k cars/week when it begins operation [7]. Since we only know it is planned to be put "partially into operation in the second half of 2019", let's guess the middle of 2019H2; that gives 13 weeks of operation, for a total of 39k cars. Added to the 306.7k baseline prediction from the first paragraph, we get to ~346k, the lower end of third bucket. Or, to work backwards: the China factory needs to make/deliver ~23k cars above the baseline prediction to put us over 330k; that's ~8 weeks at 3k/week; or ~1.8k/week if we assume they get 13 weeks of operation. When I put it this way it actually seems quite likely to me; if we assume that a significant reason for the 2018 delays was some discovery process (of how to best set up the production line etc), then the discoveries have been made, and the set up time should be much shorter now. Moreover, the baseline calculation from the first paragraph assumes production rates in the US will stay constant; but there's no reason that should be the case. Given how new the production line is, there are probably still improvements that can be made. So I rate 330k-380k as slightly more likely than 280k-330k. Dateline 1-19-2019 Some would-be customers have waited almost three years to take delivery of the Model 3, a sedan they plopped down a $1,000 deposit for as early as March 2016. Musk, Tesla’s charismatic chief executive officer, has pitched it as the company’s first car for the masses, with a base price of just $35,000. With 5 quarters to forecast and opening worldwide markets I think the key inflection point for this question is when will Tesla shift production to lower price point cars.  As the car becomes more available in different markets the level of information available goes down - the eager but less publicly engaged buyers won't be posting their VIN's to tracking sites as there's no need to wait on expected delivery dates.  The recent price drop from Tesla to assist with those buying cars after the tax credit deadline is indicative that a switch is not going to be soon - there's all of the higher priced (higher margin) European buyers to satisfy first. With 3k per week expected to be shipped to europe [1] and the level of demand for electric cars in europe significantly higher than in the US [2] then we can expect this to continue for some time.  Once orders for the initial LR version have completed a production shift to a lower price point vehicle will be needed so that the initial reservation backlog will be more than enough to keep demand exceeding supply throughout the forecast. Tesla have just released their official Model 3 Q4 delivery figures: 63,150. Increasing my forecast for total sales from 234,000 to 278,479 for the five quarters of this question. The biggest change in the input data I'm using to make this forecast is that I was assuming that Troy's estimate of underlying sales of 1,850 per week was an overestimate because of the difference between his numbers and Bloombergs. But then in the last week of 2018 Bloomberg revised their weekly sales figure up from 4,134 to 4,606 without explanation. When Teslas official Q4 delivery numbers were released today they are similar to both Troys and Bloombergs so my new forecast therefore assumes that Troy's estimate of weekly underlying sales of 1,850 is correct. Otherwise the assumptions are the same as last time; • Model 3 sales by region will be in the same proportion as those of the Model S i.e. 59% North America, 41% Rest of the World.

Oopsie, is it true that Tesla has >3,300 Model 3s in inventory? Given that the tax credit just expired, they may not be so easy to move. The just-in-time philosophy long ago led most manufacturers to abhor building up inventory. Demand ramps up, speed up the production line. Demand falters, slow the production line and deliver just in time for customer demand without building up inventory. Have you ever looks in the "back" of a department store or grocery store lately? There is no "back" in most of these because shipments go directly to the shelves. So if Tesla really has >3,300 Model 3s in inventory, OK, this is less than half of one day's delivery (769) at the lowest bucket. So this doesn't look like a big deal to me. On the other hand, the normal Tesla situation has been that sales were limited by production. Indeed, it is not unusual across the automotive industry that many sales require some waiting by the customer as the factory produces the vehicle the customer wants. Another factor -- that tax break just was cut in half. So in effect, the price of a Model 3 just rose by $3,750. Will this slow sales by much? Another consideration: could Mr. Musk be intentionally building p inventory for shipment to his newly opening market in Europe? Finally, one more consideration:  the source for the inventory data is anonymous. Dateline 12-31-2018 On Sunday, auto blog Electrek reported that there were more than 3,300 Model 3 vehicles sitting in Tesla's US inventory, according to an unnamed source familiar with the matter.  -- https://arstechnica.com/cars/2018/12/report-tesla-has-more-than-3300-model-3s-remaining-in-us-inventory/

Tesla has had a long-running goal of manufacturing 5k per week. They have recently topped out at slightly under this number [1]. For future reference here's a quick summary of the current situation.
Tesla are marketing geniuses. They created massive hype for the Model 3 and turned that hype into a reservation list. When production started, people from the reservation list were invited to place orders which created an order backlog. As weekly production volumes increased, the backlog declined and eventually disappeared which is where we are now. Anyone can now place an order and receive their car within a couple of weeks. There are people still on the reservation list but they are not placing orders, presumably because they are waiting for the promised $35k Model 3.
So the crazy production figures of 1,000 cars per day were not sustainable from a sales point of view - they were just the result of trying to clear the backlog. They were also an excellent marketing opportunity, which Tesla fully exploited. Tesla have just opened up the configurator to buyers in 5 European countries which will presumably create a similar spike in demand.
So the task is to somehow separate the short-lived demand spikes created by the reservations system, from the ongoing sales when demand settles down. That is the key to forecasting total sales for the remaining 4 quarters of this question. UPDATE 24 Dec 2018;
I think that underlying Model 3 sales (i.e. excluding the backlog) in North American are currently 1,277 per week. Bloomberg do account for those gaps, so comparing Bloombergs estimate for total weekly sales of 4,100 to Troy's of 5,900, would mean that underlying sales are 69% of Troy's estimate. So that's 69% of 1,850 = 1,277. ONGOING EDIT:

I'm going to go with the high range and hedge down to the third option.

Short of them shutting down due to Elon being indicted I don't see them reducing their production numbers. They have O(50) weeks of production worth of reservations. To put the these numbers in perspective, let's look at what they mean in terms of number of cars per week (assuming 12 weeks per quarter and 5 quarters):
- 280000: 4667
- 330000: 5500
- 380000: 6333
- 430000: 7167
Model 3 production is 4400 per week and all other models are around 2000 per week. They will have to scale up their distribution system, but essentially they shouldn't grow their "in transit" numbers too much anymore, so going forward production and deliveries should be similar. 
I probably skimmed a couple of weeks by the 12 week/quarter assumption, but looking back this should take care of any intermediate shut downs or set backs. So they are likely, even without any further scale up, to produce 380+k  vehicles, assuming not much added in transit and another couple of hundred/week potential, this should be a safe bet. Crossing 430k requires another 10-15% production increase (of M3) and it is unclear whether Tesla will be able to achieve this in Fremont (despite Elon's claims). From todays perspective this is essentially a coin toss. 
I leave a couple of points at below 280k because Elon seems to continuously taunt the authorities and another couple of points below 380k in case there is a sudden drop in demand and the 400k reservations that they still got don't get replenished (rather unlikely event though)
